Institute of Key Laboratory of Engineering Plastics and Beijing National Laboratory for Molecular Sciences Institute of Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China Graphical abstract Potassium benzimidates have been shown to efficiently initiate the ROP of ε-CL and L-LA to form linear polyesters capped with methoxy groups. By contrast, in the presence of BnOH, ROP of ε-CL afforded PCL capped with a BnO group as the major component, while ROP of L-LA gave CH3O-capped PLLA as the major species. Eight examples of potassium N-arylbenzimidates, [K2{OCPhN(2-R1,6-R2,4-R3C6H2)}2]n (R1 = R2 = R3 = H K1; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Me K2; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = OMe K3; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = F K4; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Cl K5; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = NO2 K6; R1 = R3 = H, R2 = Me K7; R1 = R2 = Me, R3 = H K8), have been prepared and characterized by spectroscopic and analytical techniques. In addition, the molecular structures of K6(3THF) and K7 were determined and shown to consist of two-dimensional coordination polymers involving combinations of π-aryl and NO2-/N-donor interactions. In the presence of benzyl alcohol (BnOH), K1 - K8 all showed high efficiency for the ROP of ε-caprolactone (ε-CL) and L-lactide (L-LA), affording linear polyesters (PCL and PLA) with BnO or CH3O end-groups (the latter derived from the quenching solvent). By contrast, lower conversions were achievable when the runs were performed in the absence of BnOH. Mechanistic studies have indicated that for runs performed with BnOH, monomer activation by benzyl alkoxide and N-arylbenzimidate were competitive pathways for the ROP of both cyclic esters. Furthermore, the nature of the N-aryl substituents influenced the ROP of ε-CL and L-LA in distinct ways. For example, K1 and K6 showed lower conversions of ε-CL than that observed for K2 - K5, K7 and K8, while the conversions of L-LA using K1 - K3 and K6 exceeded that shown by K4, K5, K7 and K8. In addition, the type of solvent greatly affected their catalytic efficiency with hexane and toluene proving superior to THF and CH2Cl2 in the ROP of ε-CL. Conversely, for L-LA almost quantitative conversions were observed in THF, CH2Cl2 and toluene while hexane was less effective. Furthermore, kinetic studies of the ROP of L-LA performed at different run temperatures highlighted the beneficial effect of higher temperature. Keywords Potassium complexes N-Arylbenzimidates Ring opening polymerization (ROP) ε-Caprolactone (ε-CL) L (L-LA) 1 Introduction Polylactide (PLA) and polycaprolactone (PCL) are among the most studied polyesters and have attracted considerable attention due to their biocompatible, biodegradable, and permeable properties that are important in biomedical and pharmaceutical applications [1–3]. Metal-catalyzed ring opening polymerization (ROP) of cyclic esters has proved a powerful method for mediating the controlled formation of such polyesters. Of the types of metal catalysts employed in ROP, stannous octoate is the most widely employed in industry. However, the presence of any trace amounts of this toxic metal within the polymer has posed questions as to its safe issue in medical and food packaging applications [4]. As a consequence, a wide range of metal catalyst systems have been investigated including those based on zinc, aluminum and rare-earth metals [5–10]. As a general observation, the type of ancillary ligand employed has been shown to play an important role by stabilizing the complex and enabling regulation in the propagation and stereo-selectivity for chiral monomers [11–19]. In the last ten years or so, alkali metal complexes have also attracted attention as catalysts for ROP of cyclic esters due to their innocuous properties, environmental benefits and abundance in the human body [20,21]. Indeed, several examples of alkali metal complexes bearing simple ligands such as hexamethyldisilazide, alkoxides, carboxylates and phenolates have emerged and they have shown excellent control in ROP and, in the case of chiral monomers, good stereo-selectivity [22–29]. For example, alkali metal aryloxyl species bearing crown ethers have exhibited high stereo-selectivity for the ROP of rac-lactides (rac-LA) [30–36]. Elsewhere, alkali metal amidinates represent another class of simple compound that have attracted attention due to the ease of preparation and straightforward modification in terms of steric and electronic properties [37]. By contrast, the application of alkali metal imidates/amidates ([RC(=NR')O]-/[RC(=O)NR']-) as catalysts in ROP are rare [38], whereas group IV transition metal amidates have received more attention [39–42]. For example, the titanium sulfonimidate A has shown good efficiency for the ROP of rac-LA affording isotactic-enriched PLA [43], while the titanium bis(pyridonate), B (Chart 1 ) and bis(amidate) C (Chart 1) were not only effective for homopolymerization of cyclic esters but also for the random copolymerization of cyclic esters [44,45]. Beyond titanium amidates, a number of rare-earth amidate complexes have been studied [46–48], including the homoleptic tris(amidate)yttrium complex D that has showed high activity for the ROP of ε-caprolactone (ε-CL) (Chart 1) [49]. Elsewhere, lanthanide bis- and tris-amidate complexes E and F (Chart 1) have shown good activity for the ROP of rac-LA [50,51] affording heterotactic-rich PLA; related bis- and mono-amidate lanthanide (Ln = La, Gd) complexes have also proved efficient catalysts for the ROP of ε-CL [52]. More recently, a series of aluminum bis(amidate) complexes G were reported but not evaluated for the ROP of cyclic esters [53]. In addition, our group has developed a family of dialkylaluminum amidates and trimetallic yttrium N-(2-methylquinolin-8-yl)benzimides that both have shown high efficiency for the ROP of ε-CL [54,55]. With the aim to explore the capacity of alkali metal amidate/imidate complexes to act as (pre)catalysts for the ROP of cyclic esters, we disclose eight examples of potassium N-arylbenzimidates that differ in the ortho-/para-substitution pattern displayed by the N-aryl group (Chart 1). An in-depth catalytic evaluation is then conducted using two types of lactone monomer, ε-CL and L-LA, in the presence or absence of benzyl alcohol as activator. In addition, the synthetic and characterization details are reported for all new complexes. 2 Experimental section 2.1 General procedures All manipulations were performed under high purity nitrogen with rigorous exclusion of air and moisture using standard Schlenk techniques or glove-boxes. Toluene, hexane, diethyl ether and THF were dried over sodium benzophenone under reflux, then distilled under nitrogen and finally stored over activated molecular sieves (4 Å) for 24 h in a glove-box prior to use. ε-CL was dried over calcium hydride and distilled under reduced pressure before use. L-LA and t BuOK were purchased from J&K Scientific and used as received. Elemental analysis was carried out with a Flash EA 1112 microanalyzer. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DMX-400 instrument. The MALDI-TOF mass spectra were recorded on Bruker autoflex Ⅲ by the linear positive ion method. The GPC measurements were performed using a system composed of a 390-LC multidetector (MDS), a 209-LC pump injection module (PIM) and a PL-GPC 50 plus instrument. THF was used as the eluent (flow rate: 1 mL/min, at 40 °C) and the molecular weights and molecular weight distributions calculated using polystyrene as the standard. The N-aryl benzamides, PhC(O)NH(2-R1,6-R2,4-R3C6H2) (R1 = R2 = R3 = H L1; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Me L2; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = OMe L3; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = F L4; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Cl L5; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = NO2 L6; R1 = R3 = H, R2 = Me L7; R1 = R2 = Me, R3 = H L8), were prepared according to a previously reported procedure [51]. 2.2 Synthesis of K1 - K8 2.2.1 Synthesis of [K2{OCPhN(C6H5)}2]n (K1) L1 (0.16 g, 0.80 mmol) and potassium tert-butoxide (0.110 g, 0.88 mmol) were added to a flask containing tetrahydrofuran (15 mL) and the reaction mixture stirred for 9 h at room temperature. Found: C, 68.09; H, 5.66; N, 5.01 %. 2.3 General procedure for the ROP of ε-CL and L-LA All procedures using ε-CL as the monomer were similar; a typical polymerization is detailed as followed using K6 as the representative precatalyst. Complex K6 (20 μmol) was introduced to a Schlenk flask containing a toluene solution of benzyl alcohol (0.2 mL, 100 μmol/mL in toluene). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 5 min before the flask was placed in a temperature-controlled oil bath preheated to the designated temperature and ε-CL (0.571 g, 5.00 mmol) and toluene (0.8 mL) promptly injected. After the mixture was stirred for the set time, the resulting viscous solution was transferred into a beaker containing cold methanol (100 mL) and stirred. The resulting polymer was collected on filter paper and dried under reduced pressure to give the PCL as a white solid. The polymerizations using L-LA as monomer were conducted using a similar procedure to that described for ROP of ε-CL. 2.4 Crystal structure determinations Single crystals of K6(3THF) and K7 suitable for the X-ray determinations were grown from a mixture of THF and hexane at room temperature. The X-ray diffraction studies were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS Rapid IP diffractometer with graphite mono-chromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ =0.71073 Å) at 173(2) K. Reflections were merged by SHELXL according to the crystal class for the calculation of statistics and refinement [56]. Intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and empirical absorption. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares on F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Structure solution were performed using OLEX2.solve and refinement was performed using the SHELXL package [57,58]. During the structure refinement of K6(3THF), there were several disordered solvent molecules that could neither be identified unambiguously nor refined well. The option SQUEEZE in the crystallographic program PLATON was used to remove these disordered solvents from the structure of K6(3THF). The geometry of the complexes themselves was not affected by using SQUEEZE. Details of the X-ray structure determination and refinement are provided in Table S1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of K1 - K8 The N-arylbenzamides, PhC(O)NH(2-R1,6-R2,4-R3C6H2) (R1 = R2 = R3 = H L1; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Me L2; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = OMe L3; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = F L4; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Cl L5; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = NO2 L6; R1 = R3 = H, R2 = Me L7; R1 = R2 = Me, R3 = H L8), were readily prepared by the reaction of the corresponding aniline with benzoyl chloride [51]. Treatment of L1 - L8 with one equivalent of potassium tert-butoxide (KO t Bu) at ambient temperature in THF afforded the corresponding potassium complexes, [K2{OCPhN(2-R1,6-R2,4-R3C6H2)}2]n (R1 = R2 = R3 = H K1; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Me K2; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = OMe K3; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = F K4; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Cl K5; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = NO2 K6; R1 = R3 = H, R2 = Me K7; R1 = R2 = Me, R3 = H K8) as white or pale yellow solids in good yield (Scheme 1 ). All complexes were characterized by 1H/13C NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. In addition, complexes K6 and K7 were the subject of single crystal X-ray diffraction studies. As a matter of course, the NMR spectra of the complexes were recorded in d6 -DMSO as their solutions in other solvents proved to be unstable in air. The absence of a NH signal (around δ 10.0) in their 1H NMR spectra was used as support for the full conversion of L1 - L8 to K1 - K8, respectively. All complexes were found to be sensitive to air with decomposition to the free ligand noted in the 1H NMR spectrum of a solid sample of K6 that was exposed to air for one day (for 1H NMR spectroscopic monitoring see Fig. S1). By contrast, the NMR spectrum of a solution of K6 in d6 -DMSO that had been exposed to air did not significantly change over time. A possible explanation for this observation is that the d6 -DMSO coordinates to the complex to generate a stable species [59]. Crystals of K6(3THF) and K7 suitable for the X-ray determinations were grown by layering their THF solutions with hexane at ambient temperature. The structures showed some differences and so will be discussed separately. A view of K6(3THF) along with its packing diagram are shown in Fig. 1 ; selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table 1 . The asymmetric unit consists of two potassium ions (K1 and K2) that are O-bridged by two N-(4-nitrophenyl)benzimidates and terminally bound by three THF molecules (one at K2 and two at K1); some additional π-stabilization of K1 by an N-aryl ring carbon is also evident [60]. Imidate ligands can adopt variety of bonding modes with N,O-chelation generally more common than O-bridging [39,61]. There is some variation in the oxygen-potassium bond distances belonging to each bridging unit with O4-K1 [2.589(3) Å] and O1-K2 [2.622(3) Å] shorter than O4-K2 [2.712(3) Å] and O1-K1 [2.706(3) Å], respectively. Inspection of the packing diagram reveals a rather more complicated situation in which each K2{N-(4-nitrophenyl)benzimidate}2(THF)3 unit is incorporated into a two-dimensional polymeric assembly in which one para-NO2 group chelates to K1 [K1-O2 2.836(3), K1-O3 3.124(3) Å], while the other both chelates to K2 [K2-O5 2.889(3), K2-O6 2.803(3) Å] and bridges the metal centers [K1-O5 2.970(3) Å]; the N1-C8 bond also undergoes an interaction with K2 (Fig. 1b). Overall two distinct coordination environments exist in the [K6(3THF)]n polymer with the coordination number of K1 being eight and K2 being six. By contrast dimeric K7 (Fig. 2 b) can be generated through symmetry of the monometallic potassium benzimidate asymmetric unit (Fig. 2a); Table 2 collects selected bond lengths and bond angles. As in K6(3THF), the N-(2-methylphenyl)benzimidate ligands in K7 act as O-bridging ligands but with the N-aryl groups now undergoing η6-π-interactions with the potassium center [K1-C 3.182–3.427 Å]; this type of alkali metal-π interaction has been reported elsewhere [62,63]. The potassium-oxygen bond distances within the bridge again show some disparity [K1-O1 2.592(17) vs. K1-O11 2.676 (17) Å]. It is uncertain why K6 forms an adduct with THF while K6 instead makes use of π-interactions to stabilize the metal center, but it may be due to the presence of electron donating 2-methyl group in K7. As shown in Fig. 2c, the formation of a two-dimensional polymer is again evident in the packing diagram in this case making use of π-interactions [K1-C141 3.196(2) Å] and σ-interactions of the imidate nitrogen atom [K1-N11 2.788(2)Å]. 3.2 ROP of ε-CL by K1 - K8 To allow a suitable set of polymerization conditions to evaluate all eight complexes, the ROP of ε-CL was firstly investigated by using K6 as the test precatalyst. Typically, the runs were conducted in toluene in the presence of BnOH and the effect of varying the temperature, run time, [ε-CL]:[K]:[BnOH] molar ratio and solvent explored; the results are listed in Table 3 . By increasing the temperature from 30 °C to 50 °C the monomer conversion using K6 was shown to improve from 55 % to 98 % over 60 min (runs 1–3, Table 3). Concomitantly, the molecular weight of the PCL gradually increased from 1.47 to 2.10 × 104 g mol−1 while the molecular weight distribution (M w/M n) became broader (from 1.36 to 1.66), the latter suggesting some transesterification at higher temperature [64,65]. The polymerization was then monitored between 15 and 60 min with the temperature maintained at 50 °C. The monomer conversion notably increased from 51 % to 97 % over longer run times (runs 3–6), while the molecular weight of the PCL also increased from 1.25 to 2.10 × 104 mol−1; similar observations have been noted elsewhere [66]. On the other hand, when the polymerization was conducted in the absence of BnOH, the efficiency for the ROP of ε-CL lowered to 79 % (c.f. 98 % with BnOH) highlighting the important role played by the BnOH (run 7, Table 3). Subsequently, with the temperature kept at 50 °C and the run time at 45 min, the polymerizations using K6 were performed by varying the molar ratio of [ε-CL]:[K]:[BnOH] from 250:1:1 to 750:1:1. The results showed a clear decrease of monomer conversion from 95 % to 25 % as the amount of ε-CL was raised (runs 7–9, Table 3). On the other hand, the molecular weight of the PCL increased from 1.58 × 104 to 2.25 × 104 g mol−1, which was consistent with higher monomer concentration favoring monomer coordination and chain propagation [67]. It should be noted that the conversion was only 7% when KO t Bu was employed as the catalyst with 250 molar equivalents of e-CL (50 °C, 45 min, toluene), which highlights the significant role played by the ligand set. To explore the effect of solvent, the polymerizations using K6 were carried out in three other solvents (THF, hexane and dichloromethane). The results showed that the monomer conversion in apolar solvents such as toluene and hexane (91–97 %) were much higher than that in polar solvents (CH2Cl2 and THF: 67–77 %) (runs 10–13, Table 3). It is likely that the competition for coordination between the monomer and THF to the potassium ion contributed to the lower activity [68,69]. Indeed, the GPC traces of the PCL in these polar solvents showed a broad bimodal distribution (M w/M n = 1.53–1.92) and the molecular weight was much lower than that in toluene. For purposes of comparison, a polymerization in the absence of solvent altogether was attempted which showed lower conversion (55 %) than that observed in toluene (run 10, Table 3). With toluene retained as the solvent, the remaining precatalysts, K1 - K5 as well as K7 and K8 were all tested for the ROP with the [ε-CL]:[K]:[BuOH] molar ratio kept at 250:1:1, the run time at 30 min and the temperature at 50 °C (runs 14–20, Table 3). The data revealed that almost all the potassium complexes showed high efficiency for the polymerization with more than 95 % monomer conversion, the exceptions being K1 and K6 which exhibited lower conversions [86 % (run 14) and 73 % (run 5)]. Generally, the complexes containing electron donating groups (K2, K3, K7, K8) showed almost quantitative conversion, which is higher than those bearing electron withdrawing groups (K4 - K6). Indeed, NO2-containing K6 was the lowest on account of the very strong electron withdrawing ability of the NO2 group. On the other hand, the resulting polymers produced by K7 and K8, containing the more bulky 2- or 2,6-substituents, exhibited higher molecular weights than that seen for K1 - K6 (all 4-substitued) (runs 14–20, Table 3). In order to gain some information about the polymerization mechanism, the structural properties of two PCL samples prepared with and without benzyl alcohol were characterized by MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry and 1H NMR spectroscopy. Firstly, the MALDI-TOF mass spectrum of PCL prepared in the absence of this alcohol was investigated (run 7, Table 3). The spectrum showed only one family of peaks (A/A*) corresponding to the linear structure, [C6H10O2]n+CH3O + Na+/K+ (Fig. 3 ). Support for the presence of a methoxide end-group was provided by the 1H NMR spectrum which showed a clear peak for the CH3O- (δ 3.67) protons (Fig. 4 a). It was assumed that the methoxy group derived from methanol used in the quenching/termination process [71]. In order to confirm this point, methanol was replaced with isopropanol resulting in a polymer incorporating −OCH(CH3)2 end-group; the 1H NMR spectrum is shown in Fig. 4 with isopropyl signals at δ 1.20, 3.56. These findings indicate that ester-exchange reactions occur during the termination step [72,73]. Based on the above observations, the mechanism for the ROP of ε-CL using K6 in the absence of BnOH was proposed as operating as shown in Scheme 2 . Following coordination of the carbonyl oxygen in ε-CL to the Lewis acidic potassium center, the activated carbonyl group undergoes nucleophilic attack by the imidate oxygen atom leading to CO bond cleavage and concomitant ring opening. Chain-propagation can then ensue with the new potassium alkoxide acting as the nucleophile; similar findings have been reported in the literature [74]. Some support for the presence of the N-(4-nitrophenyl)benzimidate in the propagating chain was provided by the 1H NMR spectrum of the polymerization mixture which revealed aromatic signals at around δ 7.30 (Fig. 4c). Following termination of the polymerization with methanol or isopropanol, the N-(4-nitrophenyl)benzimidate can then be readily exchanged for OCH3 or -OCH(CH3)2 groups, respectively as shown in Scheme 2. On the other hand, when one equivalent of BnOH was employed in combination with K6, there were two families of peaks in the MALDI-TOF mass spectrum of the resulting PCL (run 6, Table 3). The major component was assigned to a linear structure [C6H10O2]n+PhCH2O + Na+/K+ (A/A*, Fig. 5 ) containing a benzyl alkoxide end-group and the minor one to, [C6H10O2]n+CH3O + Na+/K+, incorporating a methoxide end-group (B/B*, Fig. 5). To corroborate this finding the 1H NMR spectrum of the PCL clearly showed a peak for the PhCH2O (δ 7.3, 5.2) and CH3O (δ 3.6) protons (Fig. 6 ). These results suggested that two pathways were operational when using K6/BnOH: one involving the generally accepted “monomer activated mechanism (BnOH)” and the other based on that described above (in which no BnOH was introduced) with the CH3O- end group originating from the methanol used to terminate the polymerization (Scheme 2). 3.3 ROP of L-LA using K1 - K8 The ROP of L-LA using K1 - K8 was also investigated in the presence of BnOH; the results are collected in Table 4 . As K2 showed good efficiency for the ROP of ε-CL, it was employed to optimize the conditions for the ROP of L-LA. Initially, the polymerization was conducted at 20 °C by fixing the run time at 1 h and the molar ratio of [LA]:[K]:[BnOH] at 250:1:1. Inspection of the data revealed the monomer conversion to be almost quantitative with the molecular weight distribution (M w/M n) of the poly-L-lactide (PLLA) being broad at around 2.0 (run 1, Table 4). Furthermore, there was some evidence in the GPC trace for multimodal behavior highlighting the less effective control of this polymerization. With the intent to improve the control, the polymerization using K2/BnOH was then conducted at the lower temperature of 10 °C. Inspection of the data revealed the monomer conversion decreased from 99 % to 88 %, while a slightly narrower distribution was apparent (M w/M n = 1.55) (run 2, Table 4). Next the polymerizations using K2/BnOH were performed at different time intervals with the temperature maintained at 20 °C (runs 1, 4–6, Table 4). The results showed that the monomer conversion increased from 59 % to 98 % when the run time was extended from 15−30 min, but there was almost no significant change in the molecular weight (M n = 0.86−0.95 × 104 g mol−1). In addition, the molecular weight distributions were quite broad (M w/M n = 1.69–1.99) with multimodal characteristics evident in the GPC traces even over short run times; it would seem likely that multiple active species were present at the outset of the polymerization. By fixing the run time at 30 min and the temperature at 20 °C, the role of BnOH was investigated. In the absence of BnOH, K2 showed much lower activity for the ROP of L-LA with only 4% conversion compared to that seen with one equivalent of BnOH (98 %), but nevertheless generated PLLA with similar molecular weight. On the other hand, when increasing the amount of BnOH from 1 to 5 equivalents, the monomer conversion gradually decreased from 98 % to 63 % while the molecular weight also decreased from 0.92 to 0.46 × 104 g mol−1. By comparison, using t BuOK as catalyst the conversion was only 5 % under the same conditions ([LA]:[ t BuOK]:[BnOH] = 500:1:1, 20 °C, 30 min, toluene), further underlining the important role played by the benzimidate ligand. All the GPC traces obtained using K2 showed bimodal distributions with the peak for the lower molecular material increasing with increased amounts of BnOH, suggesting a chain transfer role for the BnOH. With the temperature kept at 20 °C and the run time at 30 min, increasing the molar ratio of [L-LA]:[K2]:[BnOH] from 250:1:1 to 750:1:1 led to a rapid decrease of monomer conversion from 98 % to 13 % (runs 6–8, Table 4), while the molecular weight of the PLLA slightly increased from 0.92 × 104 to 1.16 × 104 g mol−1. Notably, the high molecular weight component in the bimodal distribution increased suggesting that higher monomer concentration favored chain propagation [75,76]. To investigate the role of solvent, the polymerizations were also conducted in THF, dichloromethane and hexane. When using THF and CH2Cl2, the conversions reached almost 100 % with the molar ratio of [L-LA]:[K2]:[BnOH] at 250:1:1 [time =30 min, temp. = 20 °C] (runs 13, 16). By stark contrast the conversion observed in hexane was only 7%. The reason could plausibly be attributed to aggregated potassium species undergoing solvation in the polar solvent resulting in various kinds of solvated complexes that were more amenable to binding to the monomer [77]. However, when further increasing the molar ratio from 250:1:1 to 750:1:1 with THF as the solvent, the conversion dramatically decreased from 100 % to 17 %, while the molecular weight remained comparable (runs 13–15, Table 4). It is unclear as to the reason behind this behavior but may be due to the increased number of impurities present in the monomer. Conversely, with CH2Cl2 as the solvent increasing the molar ratio of [L-LA]:[K2]:[BnOH] from 250:1:1 to 750:1:1 led to a more gradual decrease in the monomer conversion from 99 % to 82 %. However, further increasing the molar ratio to 1000:1:1 led to a dramatic decrease in the conversion to 14 %. On prolonging the reaction time to 2 h, the conversion could be improved to 68 %. Generally, the molecular weight of the PLLA showed a modest increase from 0.66 to 0.95 × 104 g mol−1 and the molecular weight distribution became broader (M w/M n = 1.48–2.10), suggesting that transesterification became more significant. With a view to determine the effect of temperature, the polymerization runs using K2 were conducted between 20 °C and 70 °C (runs 11, 21–24, Table 4). At 20 °C, the monomer conversion was about 54 % with the [L-LA]:[K2]:[BnOH] molar ratio at 500:1:1. However, at 70 °C the conversion significantly increased to 100 %, indicating higher temperature was beneficial to the polymerization. However, further increasing the molar ratio of [L-LA]:[K2]:[BnOH] to 1000:1 with the temperature maintained at 70 °C led to a more significant decrease in the monomer conversion. The remaining potassium complexes K1 and K3 - K8 were then investigated for the ROP of L-LA with the molar ratio of [L-LA]:[K]:[BnOH] at 500:1, the temperature at 60 °C and the run time at 30 min (runs 25–32, Table 4). The results showed K1 - K3 and K6 exhibited good efficiency with more than 90 % monomer conversion which exceeded than that seen by K4, K5, K7 and K8. It would appear that the presence of electron withdrawing para-halides (K4, K5) and more sterically bulky ortho-methyl groups (K7, K8) are detrimental to the catalytic activity. Furthermore, all the polymers obtained showed much lower molecular weight than the calculated values which suggested poor controllability. Due to the variation in polymerization behavior displayed in the ROP of ε-CL, the mechanism of the L-LA polymerization was also investigated by analysing the structural properties of the resulting PLLA. In particular, the ROP of L-LA catalysed by K2 was conducted in toluene at different temperatures and the monomer consumption monitored over time; the results are compiled in Table 5 . The data indicated that the reaction rates closely followed a first-order dependence with the polymerizations obeying the kinetic law: -d[LA]/dt = kapp[LA] (where kapp is the apparent rate constant) (Fig. S2). The similarity in the values of kapp(80 °C) and kapp(100 °C) suggested that K2 exhibited a similar polymerization rate. However, kapp(120 °C) was much higher than kapp at 80 °C and 100 °C, signifying the polymerization rate was appreciably improved at higher temperature. In addition, all the observed M n values are much lower than the calculated values and the molecular distributions of polymer were relatively broad (M w/M n = 1.76–3.43). The reason for this finding is conceivably due to a combination of greater impurities and the stronger intermolecular transesterification at high concentrations of L-LA. To gain more information on the mechanism of these L-LA polymerizations, end-group analysis of the PLLA obtained with and without benzyl alcohol using K2 was also performed by recording 1H NMR and MALDI-TOF spectra. For the run conducted in the absence of benzyl alcohol (run 6, Table 4), the MALDI-TOF mass spectrum showed two families of peaks A and B (Fig. 7 ). The major series of peaks, A/A* separated by m/z = 144, can be ascribed to CH3O + (C6H8O2)n + Na+/K+, while minor B/B* can be assigned to CH3O + (C6H8O2)n + (C3H4O2) + Na+/K+, the latter indicative of transesterification being a competitive process in the ROP. The presence of a OCH3 end group was confirmed in the 1H NMR spectrum (δ 3.71, Fig. S3); as noted earlier its presence likely deriving from methanolysis of the initial chain-end during the quenching process [72,73]. When one equivalent of BnOH was employed in the L-LA polymerization using K2 (run 5, Table 4), the MALDI-TOF mass spectrum again showed two families of peaks (Fig. 8 ), in which the major A/A* family was assigned to (C6H8O4)n + (C3H4O2) + CH3O + Na+/K+ and B/B* to (C6H8O4)n + (C3H4O2) + PhCH2O + Na+/K+; the presence of the PhCH2O methylene protons and CH3O protons in this polymer were confirmed in the 1H NMR spectrum (Fig. S4). Unlike that seen without BnOH, it is evident that intermolecular transesterification is operational for both the A and B series (Fig. 9 ). When two equivalents of BnOH were employed (run 7, Table 4), two families of peaks (A and B) with similar assignments were again observed but with a slight increase in the ratio of the B peaks; see Fig. S5 for 1H NMR spectroscopic confirmation of end-group composition. Likewise, when 10 equivalents of BnOH were employed, comparable results were also obtained with two families of peaks evident [A (major): with a CH3O end-group. B (minor); with a BnO end group] (Figs. S6 and S7). Collectively, the results observed using K2 in the L-LA polymerizations described above suggest that two mechanisms were operational namely involving paths 1 and 2 (Scheme 3 ). Path 1 is similar to the mechanism described earlier for the ROP of ε-CL (in which no BnOH was introduced) with the CH3O- end group originating from the methanol used to terminate the polymerization. Conversely, path 2 followed the “monomer activated mechanism (BnOH)” seen for most alkali metal systems [78,79], in which L-LA can be activated following coordination to the metal center and then ring-opened via nucleophilic attack of the benzyl alkoxide. Nevertheless, this polymerization still preferred to follow path 1 when in the presence of BnOH to produce linear PLLA (A/A* family), even with larger amounts of BnOH. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of potassium N-arylbenzimidates, K1 - K8, have been successfully prepared and characterized. The molecular structures of K6 and K7 revealed combinations of π- and σ-interactions leading to two-dimensional polymeric assemblies. In the presence of BnOH, all complexes showed high efficiency for the ROP of ε-CL and L-LA. For ε-CL, conversions of higher than 95 % were observed with a [ε-CL]:[K] molar ratio of 250:1 and the temperature at 50 °C. By comparison, much higher activities for the ROP of L-LA were achieved, in which conversions could reach 100 % in 30 min with the [L-LA]:[K] molar ratio at 500:1. Structural analysis of the PCL indicated linear polymeric structures capped with BnO- groups as the major component which has been credited to an activated monomer mechanism being operational in the presence of BnOH. By comparison, the structural analysis of the PLLA also showed the major product to be a linear polymer but in this case capped with a CH3O end group (originating from the quenching reagent). On the other hand, the linear PCL or PLLA obtained when the polymerizations were conducted in the absence of BnOH were both capped with CH3O groups. In addition, the reaction solvent was shown to have an influential effect on the polymerizations with the ROP of ε-CL in hexane and toluene allowing conversions of over 90 %, which are much higher than in THF and CH2Cl2 (65–77 %). Conversely, essentially full conversions were observed in THF, CH2Cl2 and toluene for the ROP of L-LA, which was much higher than that observed in hexane (7%). coredata.dc:description: Eight examples of potassium N-arylbenzimidates, [K2{OCPhN(2-R1,6-R2,4-R3C6H2)}2]n (R1 = R2 = R3 = H K1; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Me K2; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = OMe K3; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = F K4; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = Cl K5; R1 = R2 = H, R3 = NO2 K6; R1 = R3 = H, R2 = Me K7; R1 = R2 = Me, R3 = H K8), have been prepared and characterized by spectroscopic and analytical techniques. In addition, the molecular structures of K6(3THF) and K7 were determined and shown to consist of two-dimensional coordination polymers involving combinations of π-aryl and NO2-/N-donor interactions. In the presence of benzyl alcohol (BnOH), K1 - K8 all showed high efficiency for the ROP of ε-caprolactone (ε-CL) and L-lactide (L-LA), affording linear polyesters (PCL and PLA) with BnO or CH3O end-groups (the latter derived from the quenching solvent). By contrast, lower conversions were achievable when the runs were performed in the absence of BnOH. Mechanistic studies have indicated that for runs performed with BnOH, monomer activation by benzyl alkoxide and N-arylbenzimidate were competitive pathways for the ROP of both cyclic esters. Furthermore, the nature of the N-aryl substituents influenced the ROP of ε-CL and L-LA in distinct ways. For example, K1 and K6 showed lower conversions of ε-CL than that observed for K2 - K5, K7 and K8, while the conversions of L-LA using K1 - K3 and K6 exceeded that shown by K4, K5, K7 and K8. In addition, the type of solvent greatly affected their catalytic efficiency with hexane and toluene proving superior to THF and CH2Cl2 in the ROP of ε-CL. Conversely, for L-LA almost quantitative conversions were observed in THF, CH2Cl2 and toluene while hexane was less effective. Furthermore, kinetic studies of the ROP of L-LA performed at different run temperatures highlighted the beneficial effect of higher temperature.
coredata.dc:title: Potassium N-arylbenzimidates as readily accessible and benign (pre)catalysts for the ring opening polymerization of ε-CL and L-LA
